metadata.case_name: Assessee (Subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd.) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee is a 100% subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd. (I.C.I.), incorporated in the United Kingdom.

I.C.I. advanced large amounts by way of loans to the assessee from time to time for subscribing to shares in three Indian companies: Indian Explosives Ltd. (I.E.L.), Alkalai Chemical Corporation of India (A.C.C.I.) and Atic Industries Private Ltd. (ATIC).
The assessee transferred the shares in the aforesaid companies at par to I.C.I. in satisfaction of the loans advanced by I.C.I.
Income-tax Officer applied S. 52 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 and assessed the assessee to capital gains.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that assessee was not liable to capital gains under S. 52 on the facts established.
Appellate Tribunal upheld the decision of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner by a detailed and well reasoned order.
I.C.I. wanted to make investments in India in sterling currency; assessee was already in existence, other three companies incorporated later.

Scheme devised by I.C.I.: loans to assessee to hold shares in three companies, to be transferred to I.C.I. at par or issue price as desired; to take advantage of tax relief under S. 15C and 56A of 1922 Act.
Scheme conceived and put into operation prior to 30th November 1956 when Finance Bill reimposed capital gains tax.
Negotiations with concerned Department of Government of India at highest level and approval of Reserve Bank of India.
Interest provision: not exceeding 1/2 above Indian Bank rate (5.5% p.a.), but not to exceed dividends received by assessee.
Arrangement advantageous: I.C.I. took risk of depreciation, got capital appreciation; assessee paid no interest if no dividend, kept excess dividends.
I.C.I. saved tax in U.K. amounting to Â£68,000 due to holding through assessee.
In 1959, Finance Act abolished grossing up of dividends under S.16(2) and 18(5) of 1922 Act; intercorporate dividends taxable at each stage, affecting I.C.I.'s net return.
I.C.I. decided to hold investments directly; called upon assessee in February 1961 to transfer shares at issue price in satisfaction of loans.
Reserve Bank approval for transfers received February 1961; transfers made March-April 1961.
In or about 1949, Government of India asked I.C.I. to consider manufacture of commercial lasting high explosives in India.
Negotiations advanced October 1953; meetings on 1st and 6th October 1953.
Declaration of Intention dated 5-11-1953: Government agreed if I.C.I. loaned to assessee, latter holds shares in I.E.L., repayable by transfer at any time.
21-12-1954: Assessee applied to RBI for sanction to borrow Rs. 160 lakhs from I.C.I. for I.E.L. shares; no interest until dividends.
Loans advanced 30-09-1954 to 30-06-1957 equivalent to Rs. 160 lakhs in sterling.
1958 Rights Issue by I.E.L.: I.C.I. loaned Rs. 80 lakhs to assessee; right to acquire shares at par; interest 1% above bank rate.
Resolution 30-09-1958 confirming second loan Rs. 80 lakhs.
15-02-1961: I.C.I. called for transfer of I.E.L. investments.
13-12-1955: Assessee letter to Govt. re A.C.C.I.: I.C.I. to lend subscription monies, acquire shares later at issue price.
Affidavits: P.T. Manzies 17-08-1966, U.R. Newbery 10-01-1967 re A.C.C.I.
29-12-1955: I.C.I. agreed Rs. 25 lakhs loan to assessee for ATIC shares, transferable at issue price; interest waived until dividends.
Further loan Rs. 35 lakhs to assessee for ATIC on same terms.
ATIC shares transferred February 1961.
Department accepted affidavits as correct on facts, disputed inferences.
Commissioner applied for reference of six questions; Tribunal rejected on 28-07-1969; four pressed.
Calcutta High Court on 08-09-1970 directed Tribunal to draw statement of case on four questions without reasons.
Assessment year 1962-63.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transfer of shares was effected with the object of avoidance or reduction of the liability of the assessee to capital gains tax under S. 52 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
Whether questions of law arose out of the Tribunal's order for reference under S. 256.
Whether the Tribunal's findings were perverse or unsupported by evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: The scheme was devised prior to reimposition of capital gains tax in 1956; loans advanced with understanding shares would be transferred at par to I.C.I.; no object of avoiding capital gains; transfers due to change in dividend taxation in 1959.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 52 Income-tax Act, 1961 requires reason to believe transfer effected for avoidance/reduction of capital gains liability

petitioner_arguments.text: Arrangement from inception: I.C.I. not making assessee real beneficial owner; supported by correspondence, government negotiations, RBI approvals, affidavits.
Absence of enforceable agreement irrelevant; object not tax avoidance as scheme predated tax reimposition; businessmen not always legalistic.

respondent_arguments.text: Transfer effected with object of avoidance/reduction of capital gains liability under S.52; connected person (I.C.I.); no enforceable agreement until transfer.
Tribunal ignored essential evidence; findings perverse; questions of law arise on construction of documents.
Accepted affidavits factually correct but disputed inferences.

court_reasoning.text: Ingredients of S.52: (i) direct/indirect connection (satisfied); (ii) ITO reason to believe object was avoidance/reduction of capital gains (not satisfied, question of fact); no material showing such object.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intention/object is question of fact from relevant material; Tribunal examined correspondence fully.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal satisfied transfers at par basis of loans throughout; scheme predated capital gains reimposition; no enforceable agreement irrelevant as object not tax avoidance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In 1953 no mention of capital gains revival; cannot infer object from results.

court_reasoning.text: No question of law arises: pure facts; Tribunal findings final, supported by evidence, not perverse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reference under S.256 only for pure law, mixed law-fact, or perverse facts; here pure facts/inferences.

court_reasoning.text: High Court failed to give reasons; jurisdiction limits cited.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount large but irrelevant for reference on facts.

holdings.text: S.52 not applicable as no factual basis for object of avoidance/reduction of capital gains liability.
No question of law arises from Tribunal order; High Court erred in directing reference.
Tribunal findings on facts pure questions of fact, amply supported, reasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Findings of fact by Tribunal final unless perverse/no evidence; no reference on pure facts even if inferences.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: S.52 applies only if ITO has reason to believe transfer by connected person effected to avoid/reduce capital gains; full value taken as FMV; reference only if question of law.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax relief for new enterprises; grossing up abolished 1959; reference principles apply similarly.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of Calcutta High Court dated 08-09-1970 set aside; Tribunal not required to refer questions as no question of law arose.
outcome.relief_granted: Assessee not liable under S.52; costs in this Court to assessee.
outcome.costs: Assessee entitled to costs in Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "the intention with which a particular transfer is made and the object which is to be achieved by such transfer is essentially a question of fact"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines applicability of S.52 as factual determination.

key_quotes.text: "We have to find out the object of the transaction. It is removed in point of time from the result. In such a case one cannot try to infer the object from the results."
key_quotes.speaker: tribunal
key_quotes.significance: Explains why tax motive cannot be inferred post-facto.

key_quotes.text: "the findings of the Tribunal were amply supported by evidence and were eminently reasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
